Award.AwardTitle: Akeakamai I Ka La Hiki Ola: Scientific Exploration Beneath The Life-Bringing Sun (NSF ATST Mitigation Plan)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Description of the Project:

Funding for the construction of the Advanced Technology Solar Telescope (ATST) near the summit of Haleakala on Maui, Hawaii began in FY 2010. Since it is funded with Federal funds, ATST construction is a Federal undertaking that must comply with a number of environmental and historic preservation statutes. The impacts of the ATST construction on the environmental, historical, and cultural assets atop Haleakala were the subject of a nearly five-year study that culminated in a Final Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS) that was completed in August 2009.

Since the summit of Haleakala is a ?traditional cultural place? that has cultural and spiritual significance to native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders, the FEIS stipulates that the construction of the ATST will have impacts on the spiritual and cultural assets there. A number of mitigation activities designed to minimize or mitigate such impacts are described in the compliance documents and are memorialized in the Record of Decision signed by former NSF Director, Arden L. Bement, Jr. in December 2009. One of these designed to mitigate the direct, major, adverse, and long-term impacts to the summit as a TCP is through education and workforce development. This award provides funding for a ten-year program at the University of Hawaii Maui College that will address the intersection between traditional Native Hawaiian culture and science.

This program will employ STEM educational strategies informed by traditional Native Hawaiian approaches to learning. AIK will create a ?pipeline? of Native Hawaiian STEM students from Maui County secondary schools by identifying and preparing students early in their education, with the support of secondary school math and science teachers and staff. The plan includes development of STEM curricula in the Hawaiian language, STEM faculty development at both secondary and postsecondary levels, and also seeks to engage parents, families, prospective employers, and community members, as well as various Native Hawaiian student networks, through a variety of community partner programs.

Broader Impacts and Importance

By integrating science with Native Hawaiian culture, this plan offers an innovative design for helping native peoples access 21st century economic opportunities. This plan also seeks to demonstrate to the Native Hawaiian and broader community that there exists space within the STEM community for native knowledge, experiences, and ways of learning to make significant contribution. Programs that are developed in this plan will benefit both Native Hawaiian and other Maui County and UHMC students. Finally, the complex social and environmental issues that confront the Hawaiian Islands require that the next generation of leaders be conversant in both science and culture. This plan addresses this need, by bringing together existing STEM scientific, Native Hawaiian cultural, and secondary and post-secondary educational resources to create a cohort of future leaders from an underserved population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018-2019 annual reporting year has been successful in many ways.

Goal 1 of increasing the number of Maui County Native Hawaiian graduates who complete prpatory calsses and are admitted to UHMC has declined because we have only 2 more years left in our grant, we are still accepting students into our Manaiakalani program for first time college students but we are no longer doing our Summer Bridge program because we will not be able to see those students to graduation because of grant sunset. These numbers have been consistently about 60 students for the last 3 years and we anticipate the same numbers for this AY 2019-2020. In addition, students in our individualized precollege classes remain steady as 24 paticipating seniors anticipate attendance in the University of Hawaiʻi school system.

Goal 2 of incrasing the number of UHMC Native Hawaiian students in the STEM classes as well as Hawaiian Studies graduating with the Associates  and Bachelor degrees remained steady at 23. Because our grant will sunset in Spring 2021, we are looking at assisting students to pursue the next level of degrees as well as increasing the scholarship awards to assist in successful completion. We anticipate that we will be able to graduate students in higher degree levels over the next two years.

Goal 3 includes increasing UHMC and other Native Hawaiian college graduateds who are placed in STEM and STEM-related jobs is closely related to our Internship program. This year was a difficulty year with only 13 completed internships compared to 28 last academic year. In our community, more short-term internships are being offered to students as purely work experience but no commitment by the community partner. This seems to be what the student is pursuing since it allows them to continue their college classes while giving them work experience. We will try to redesign our current offerings and partnerships with our community partners.

Goal 4 to ensure Native Hawaiian employment in STEM fields by creating a feedback system has been the most difficult to do but we are currently creating this feedback and tracking systems with our College technology department. We anticipate being able to give a better report on this in the future. In July 2019 we should have a computer network that can store student data of current and past scholars. We anticipate being able to have a better idea of where our graduates are and what they are currently doing.

Goal 5 to expand and sustain opportunities to prepare Native Hawaiian students in STEM and STEM related jobs through an alumni association is closely related to the activities in Goal 4. The feedback and tracking system will be the foundation of the alumni association which will help our students network and share as well as become mentors to other scholars.

All in all we look forward to an exciting 2019-2020 Academic Year. We see that we will be able to continue to assist our scholars with reaching their academic goals.
